this is a great improvement against using some heuristics (for automatically allowing names, which cannot be Matlab func calls) without this list.

- backend: computation of stop messages
- ECS: stop queue
Some work, because for CC there is the need of introducing an extra thread/process for polling stop queue and killing computation after stop command: so far nothing is running in parallel; there are child processes, but main proc waits for them (and/or a timeout).

1299596013859_2_1.name: 500er workaround against ECS bugs
1299596013859_2_1.description:
there are different policies:
- CCs have to poll their solution queue indefinitely, but
- STCs shouldn't do the same, if waiting for a computation result. In case of a permanent error - waiting forever for some result - the STC would not send any new stress test then, which is not in the spirit of a stress test.

1300968016075_2_16.name: impl 3b: cleanup computation dirs differently in normal and no-maintainer mode
1300968016075_2_16.description:
- no-maintainer mode: brute-force cleanup
- normal mode: do *not* clean computation dirs in case of serious errors
  - Policy:
    - system errors (CC, sys as a whole) -> no computation dir cleanup
    - student error -> always computation dir cleanup

1304547076990_1_1.name: memory leak problem
1304547076990_1_1.description:
- Seems to depend mainly from real run time and not from numbers of computations performed:
  -> Curl?
- CCs need more and more mem if running for a longer time (days): luckily mem consumptions increases slowly.
- Leak may stay in used libraries:
  -> Curl lib (or libs used by it) is main suspect

1305029595737_1_5.name: clearify resource limit mechanism
1305029595737_1_5.description:
- needed CPU time of DuMuX executables < 1min

  -> no mechanism for controlling resource limits by teacher frontend

- log stats
- exit

-> needed for use of valgrind (searching for mem leaks)

1306430134344_1_1.name: element -> file mapping: move away from element to elementMap

1306481919233_1_1.name: [meeting][Heiko, Thomas, Stephan] discuss Solution queue behavior

1306481919233_1_3.text:
Idea: ECS plugin for routing Solutions according Exercise config
================================================================
ECS:
- if there is routing semantics in ECS - named different Solution queues -,
  -> we also could look into Solutions/Exercises for dynamic routing;
- central routing point,
- plugin could be extended to smartly serve Interrupt queues for stopping long running tasks,

Problem
-------
Solution only contains reference to Exercise (which contains 'config').
Variants:
- ECS looking into Solution, then looking into Exercise for config, or
- student client copying some config data into Solution (it already *has* looked into Exercise).
Is there a better way?

Chosen Alternative (after meeting with Heiko + Thomas)
------------------
Queue will be chosen by routing->solutionQueue-><string> entry in Exercise:
- set programmatically by teacher frontend (just switched by language choice)
  <- customer (teacher) has control
  this is in opposite to my - older (!) - thinking, that
  - we want to have more control here,
  - Thomas don't want to have this choice in teacher frontend (what is wrong now)
-> plugin idea could be realized if there is a need later.

1310670605087_1_1.name: cURL mem leak workaround
1310670605087_1_1.description:
- valgrind has supported the assumption of a mem leak inside cURL
-> solution is to avoid DNS lookup for ECS connections (as far as it makes sense)

1311260501578_1_1.text:
Error 'Taxonomy'
----------------
- expectation: "mayHappen" | "shouldNotHappen"
- where: "internal" | "external" (matlab, gcc)
- returnCode: 1..127, only, if "where":"external"
- typeSpecific
  - "output" | "input" | "timeout", if where:"internal"
  - "system", if typeGeneric:"internalUnexpected"
  - "start" // may occur in both typeGeneric:"internalExpected", typeGeneric:"internalUnexpected"
- position: [object]
- message: [string]

1311587629828_1_26.text:
Result error object spec
========================
error_object
  Matlab_error_object
  C_error_object

Matlab chain error object spec
------------------------------
#@@@
Matlab_error_object::
{
  "type"   : "system"
             | "interpreter" // external
             | "callcheck", // internal
  <1>"info": error_info_object // <1> just there, if "type":"interpreter"
}
#@@@

C chain error object spec
-------------------------
#@@@
C_error_object::
{
  "type"       : "system"
                 | "compiler"|"linker"|"executable" // external
                 | "callcheck", // internal
  <1>"exitCode": 1..127, // <1> just there, if 'type': "compiler"|"linker"|"executable"
  <2>"info"    : error_info_object // <2> just there, if "type": "compiler"|"linker"
                 | [ +error_info_object ] // compilation of multiple sources
}
#@@@

error_info object spec (part of error_object)
----------------------
#@@@
error_info_object::
{
  "output"    :
  {
    "elementID": string, // "identifier" of Result element containing error suggesting interpreter/compiler output (stderr)
    "extract"  : string  // opt: extracted error output
  },
  <1>?"source": // <1> opt, but only allowed, if "type": "compiler"|"interpreter"|"callcheck"
  {
    "elementID": string, // "identifier" of Result element containing error producing *input*
    "row"      : 1..uint_max,
    "col"      : 1..uint_max,
    ?"extract" : string // opt: extracted error info related to location given
  }
}
#@@@
Note: if "type":"system" whole Result should be included into a bug report.
Note: compiler output may contain multiple error positions; only the first one should be extracted.

1311672821145_1_4.text:
JSON Schema Example
===================
Informal Notation
-----------------
- '<ident>': condition, which have to be fulfilled before the rest of the item applies. If it is not fulfilled, the item will be omitted. It can be referred to later - by '<ident>' - and may contain a more or less formal description of the condition.
- '?': optional.
- '!': negation.

Example
-------
Explanations:
- '<1>?"source":...' means, that after fulfilling condition '<1>' (explained in the comment), there is an optional item '"source":...'. If the condition is not fulfilled, the item ***must not*** be there.
- '?"extract" :...': optional.
#@@@
error_info_obj::
{
  "output"  :
  {
    "elementID": string, // "identifier" of Result element containing error suggesting interpreter/compiler output (stderr)
    "extract"  : string  // opt: extracted error output
  },
  <1>?"source": // <1> opt, but only allowed, if "type": "compiler"|"interpreter"|"callcheck"
  {
    "elementID": string, // "identifier" of Result element containing error producing *input*
    "row"      : 1..uint_max,
    "col"      : 1..uint_max,
    ?"extract" : string // opt: extracted error info related to location given
  }
}

1311672821145_1_6.text:
JSON Schema Grammar
===================
www.json.org
------------
*object*
    {}
    { *members* } 
*members*
    *pair*
    *pair* , *members*
*pair*
    *string* : *value*
*array*
    []
    [ *elements* ]
*elements*
    *value*
    *value* , *elements*
*value*
    *string*
    *number*
    *object*
    *array*
    true
    false
    null
|---------------------------------------------------------------|
Extended Grammar
----------------
*Object*
    Object 
    {}
    { *Members* }
    *Pre* *Object*
*Members*
    *MemberExpr*
    *MemberExpr* , *Members*
*MemberExpr*
    *InnerMemberExpr*
    *Label* *InnerMemberExpr*
    *InnerMemberExpr* *Label*
    *Label* *InnerMemberExpr* *Label*
*InnerMemberExpr*
    *Pair*
    *BracketedMembers*
    *BracketedMembers* *Bin* *BracketedMembers*
    ( *MemberExpr* )
    *Pre* *InnerMemberExpr*
*BracketedMembers*
    ( *Members* )
*Pair*
    *String* : *ValueExpr*
    *Pre* *Pair*
*ValueExpr*
    InnerValueExpr
    *Label* *InnverValueExpr*
*InnerValueExpr*
    *Value*
    *InnerValueExpr* *Bin* *InnerValueExpr*
    ( *InnerValueExpr* )
    *Pre* *InnerValueExpr*
*Label*
    < *ident* >
*Array*
    Array 
    []
    [ *Elements* ]
    *Pre* *Array*
*Elements*
    *ValueExpr*
    *ValueExpr* , Elements*
*Value*
    *String* 
    *Number*
    *Object*
    *Array*
    *Bool*
    *Range*
    null
*String*
    String
    *string*
*Number*
  Number
  *Int*
  *Float*
*Int*
    Int
    *int*
*Float*
    Float
    *float*
*Bool*
    Bool
    true
    false
*Range*
    Range
    *IntRange*
    *FloatRange*
*IntRange*
    IntRange
    *Int* .. *Int*
*FloatRange*
    FloatRange
    *Float* .. *Float*
*Pre*
    *
    +
    ?
    !
*Bin*
    |
    &
    ^
*Enum*
  Enum
  *value*
  ( *EnumExpr* )
*EnumExpr*
    *Enum*
    *EnumExpr* | *Enum*
    ( *EnumExpr* )

not so clear
------------
- Enum: needed at all? Could be realized by '|'ring *Value* (*ValueExpr*)
- recursitivity of *Bin* ops: should better only be recursive at one of both sides...

1312202957195_1_5.name: Matlab chain: interpreter prestart
1312202957195_1_5.description: Idea is to have the Matlab interpreter started in advance *before* there is a computation coming in: saves startup time.

1312202957195_1_7.name: measure startup time of Matlab interpreter
1312202957195_1_7.description:
sr@numlab:/tmp/TTT$ time matlab -nodisplay -nojvm 2>&1 > res.txt < quit.cmd 

real    0m3.362s
user    0m1.960s
sys     0m0.280s
sr@numlab:/tmp/TTT$ time matlab -nodisplay -nojvm 2>&1 > res.txt < quit.cmd 

real    0m3.458s
user    0m2.084s
sys     0m0.244s
sr@numlab:/tmp/TTT$ time matlab -nodisplay -nojvm 2>&1 > res.txt < quit.cmd 

real    0m3.429s
user    0m2.040s
sys     0m0.268s

'quit' times after startup negligable: so prestart could save > 3s real and about 2s user/sys computation time.

1314362661116_1_1.name: [security] perms of prestart dir
1314362661116_1_1.description:
After Matlab prestart it would be good to limit prestart dir perms for not giving access to potentially evil other computations.
Problem here is, that this can be done only, *after* Matlab has finished its startup (it needs these perms).
